body: Sorry it's not supported. Welcome to contribute.

You can use https://github.com/graphitemaster/incbin to embed the weights in your executable. Then you won't have any dangling files. But someone can figure out the offset of the file in your executable then read it.
I ended up writing my own encypter for ONNX models....

> I ended up writing my own encypter for ONNX models....

Dear John, would you mind sharing a few more details about the approach you have used to encrypt your ONNX models?

Thanks!

alekk -- the key thing to know is that there is a constructor defined for Session that takes a data buffer (for the model).  Previously, I had always used the constructor that takes a string path to the model file on disk.  But since a handy constructor exists using a data buffer, one can stream the (encrypted) file in, then unencrypt the buffer, then hand the buffer to the Session constructor.  This way, the model file written on disk (and subject to theft) is always an encrypted file.  Hope that helps.  If so, you owe me one!

I used pyAesCrypt to decrypt the model. Therefore I looked into the code of `onnx.save_model()` and got the code I need and added the decryption to it. 
Let me sketch it for you. You might need other functions from the `save_model` when you have some special onnx models.
For me the `onnx.save_model` did nothing but:
```
// proto = keras2onnx.convert_keras(...) //create onnx model
// keras2onnx.save_model(proto, filePath) // replaced by the next three lanes
pString = proto.SerializeToString()
from typing import cast, Text
with open(cast(Text, filePath), "wb") as writable:
    writable.write(pString)
```
So I replaced the last three lines with
```        
fIn = io.BytesIO(pString)
with open(onnxPath.with_suffix(".onnx_enc8"), "wb") as fOut:
    pyAesCrypt.encryptStream(fIn, fOut, password, bufferSize)
```
How to encrypt and decrypt with pyAesCrypt is explained here: https://github.com/marcobellaccini/pyAesCrypt

So overall replace `keras2onnx.save_model(proto, filePath)` with:
```
import pyAesCrypt
bufferSize = 64 * 1024
password = "adobe123"
pString = proto.SerializeToString()
fIn = io.BytesIO(pString)
with open(onnxPath.with_suffix(".onnx_enc8"), "wb") as fOut:
    pyAesCrypt.encryptStream(fIn, fOut, password, bufferSize)
```

> Sorry it's not supported. Welcome to contribute.

Hi @snnn 
I know the ticket is closed but the question for onnxrt to support encrypted models is still open.
Encrypting the onnx file could be done offline using whatever framework used for training.
What is missing is an option/addon for onnxrt to decrypt it using a given key.
I know it s possible to manually do it by first decrypting in ram and then loading the onnx Session from a mem buffer.
But this is adding an extra layer that would also have to be protected against hacking and that could be done by onnxrt internally.
It would just need :
- a AES decryt implementation : that could be provided by any header only lib as plusaes (see ref).
- a new onnxrt Sessions load API method taking an extra param for the key

Any cons/would you accept a PR ?
Kind
WT.
Refs:
https://github.com/kkAyataka/plusaes
https://medium.com/@ovechko.056/tensorflow-pretrained-model-encryption-decryption-in-mobile-apps-e3e95209716a

I feel people often get confused by two concepts: encryption and obfuscation. I feel what you want is obfuscation, which is for making reverse engineering difficult. And AES doesn't do any help on that.  For example, if you have a OAUTH2 API key and you want to keep it private to your application, you need to obfuscation your application so that people like me can't put a debugger on it.  There are a lot of commercial SDKs(e.g. VMProtect) to help this, and it is far beyond of onnxruntime's scope. 

What onnxruntime would do is adding confidential computing support. Like: https://azure.microsoft.com/en-us/solutions/confidential-compute/ .

Hi @snnn 
On our side I confirm that we are in need of :  
- encrypting the onnx file on disk to prevent anyone to load/use it with any framework capable to import onnx files
- decrypt the onnx on the fly, given a key, at model loading time with onnxrt

For that use case, confidential computing/obfuscation would nt help much here, the priority being to make the onnx file that we deliver to our customers unusable without our software.
Another similar request here:
https://github.com/onnx/onnx/issues/3223#issuecomment-860333626

Kind regards
WT

> Hi @snnn
> On our side I confirm that we are in need of :
> 
> * encrypting the onnx file on disk to prevent anyone to load/use it with any framework capable to import onnx files
> * decrypt the onnx on the fly, given a key, at model loading time with onnxrt
> 
> For that use case, confidential computing/obfuscation would nt help much here, the priority being to make the onnx file that we deliver to our customers unusable without our software.
> Another similar request here:
> [onnx/onnx#3223 (comment)](https://github.com/onnx/onnx/issues/3223#issuecomment-860333626)
> 
> Kind regards
> WT

I'm in a similar situation. This feature would be really useful!

issue.title: [Snyk] Upgrade @typescript-eslint/parser from 4.22.1 to 4.28.0

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
Snyk has created this PR to upgrade @typescript-eslint/parser from 4.22.1 to 4.28.0.

![merge advice](https://app.snyk.io/badges/merge-advice/?package_manager=npm&package_name=@typescript-eslint/parser&from_version=4.22.1&to_version=4.28.0&pr_id=195e4a2e-5cca-49cd-aa9f-9ac26d2dc7ae&visibility=true&has_feature_flag=false) :information_source: Keep your dependencies up-to-date. This makes it easier to fix existing vulnerabilities and to more quickly identify and fix newly disclosed vulnerabilities when they affect your project.
- The recommended version is **109 versions** ahead of your current version. - The recommended version was released **24 days ago**, on 2021-06-21. The recommended version fixes: Severity | Issue | PriorityScore (*) | Exploit Maturity | :-------------------------:|:-------------------------|-------------------------|:------------------------- | Regular Expression Denial of Service (ReDoS)
[SNYK-JS-PATHPARSE-1077067](https://snyk.io/vuln/SNYK-JS-PATHPARSE-1077067) | **265/1000**
**Why?** CVSS 5.3 | No Known Exploit (*) Note that the real score may have changed since the PR was raised.

body:
@snnn 
Can we implement model encryption by renaming or obfuscating OP? I think you should have a model encryption scheme！

issue.title: [React Native Inference Session Initialization With Buffer Error] "Error: Uint8Array is not supported"

labels.name: platform:mobile
labels.description: issues related to ONNX Runtime mobile; typically submitted using template

repository.name: onnxruntime
repository.description: ONNX Runtime: cross-platform, high performance ML inferencing and training accelerator

issue.body:
### Describe the bug
I tried to initialize an inference session with a Uint8Array representation of a very simple .ort model (see screenshot of the .ort file viewed in Netron below), but it gave me the `[Error: Uint8Array is not supported]` error. The Uint8Array from my original code is from my database, but for the purpose of easier reproduction and isolation of the issue, I have included a .txt file that contains the content of the .ort file in hex code (see [https://github.com/jackylu0124/ort-react-native-buffer-issue/blob/main/onnx_hex_files/LinearBlend_v001.txt](https://github.com/jackylu0124/ort-react-native-buffer-issue/blob/main/onnx_hex_files/LinearBlend_v001.txt)), and the string of the hex code content (see [line 46 in App.tsx](https://github.com/jackylu0124/ort-react-native-buffer-issue/blob/ec97f606bf32743f63b42b76d40c6e51b938c337/BufferInitializationTestApp/App.tsx#L46)) is parsed into a Uint8Array buffer before it's being passed into `ort.InferenceSession.create()`. I have also tried passing in a raw ArrayBuffer rather than a Uint8Array buffer, but it didn't work either. According to the documentation ([https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/api/js/interfaces/InferenceSessionFactory.html](https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/api/js/interfaces/InferenceSessionFactory.html)), both should work.

I am currently running the app on Android Studio's emulator on Windows.

P.S.
[I have verified that the hex code content in the .txt file is correct by parsing it and converting it to bytes in Python and was able to use it to initialize an inference session successfully using ONNX Runtime's Python API](https://github.com/jackylu0124/ort-react-native-buffer-issue/blob/main/onnx_hex_files/onnx_get_hex.ipynb) (but the same doesn't work for ONNX Runtime's React Native API, and hence leading to this GitHub issue).

### Urgency
High urgency, this is a blocking issue in my project.

### System information
- OS Platform and Distribution (e.g., Linux Ubuntu 16.04): Windows 10
- ONNX Runtime version: `"onnxruntime-react-native": "^1.12.1"` (in package.json)

### To Reproduce
Link to repo with minimal code for error reproduction: https://github.com/jackylu0124/ort-react-native-buffer-issue
Please follow instructions on https://reactnative.dev/docs/environment-setup in order to set up and run the project with Android Studio's emulator.

Once the project is set up and running, you can click/press the "CREATE INFERENCE SESSION WITH BUFFER" button on the top of the screen, which will try to initialize an inference session with the Uint8Array buffer representing the ONNX model, and the error will be logged into the console. (see Gif below)

### Expected behavior
The inference session should be initialized successfully with no error messages emitted since initializing inference session with Uint8Array buffer or raw ArrayBuffer is supported as stated in the documentation. ([https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/api/js/interfaces/InferenceSessionFactory.html](https://onnxruntime.ai/docs/api/js/interfaces/InferenceSessionFactory.html)).

### Screenshots
**The .ort Model that I am using (it's a very simple model for linear-blending two inputs e.g. `blend = (1 - alpha) * img1 + alpha * img2)`**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28615340/183332626-7c6d11fd-e241-4035-8223-aaf6a378e806.png)
**Error Message Gif**
![ort_react_native_buffer_issue_0807_2022](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/28615340/183339613-a1b15528-8942-495d-bc28-37287c8002db.gif)
